This displays image.png with a red border that's 3 pixels big.

title: Re: Mods
content:
Make a page called 404.htm and put a 404-related error message in it. Then create a new file called .htaccess and put the following in it:
[pre] ErrorDocument 404 /error.htm[/pre]
Whenever your visitors try to access a file that does not exist, they'll get that message.

It's appearing in the "qlitenews" subfolder. This suggests that you need to include it on your index page. To do so:

2. Open up the newly renamed index.php.

title: Re: Planet CK
content:
Your site design isn't bad, but it shouldn't be made with tables (hiss).

CSS is able to both style and position your page. For example, take [url=http://csszengarden.com]CSS Zen Garden[/url]. How is it that designers are able to tranform [url=http://www.csszengarden.com/zengarden-sample.html]this[/url] into [url=http://www.csszengarden.com/?cssfile=/177/177.css&page=0]this[/url] or [url=http://csszengarden.com/?cssfile=157/157.css]this[/url] without changing the HTML? The answer is CSS.

The problem with CSS is that whilst it is incredibly useful for styling your page, positioning takes a little more getting used to. Here's an example of a basic HTML document, no styling:[pre] <html><head><title>My Test Page</title></head><body><h1>My Test Page!</h1><h2>What this is about</h2><p>This is a page that has no styling or extra markup. It is simply here to demonstrate how to change the style of a page using only CSS. This is a page that has no styling or extra markup. It is simply here to demonstrate how to change the style of a page using only CSS. This is a... {etc}</p></body></html>[/pre]
And this will give you something like [url=http://www.stephenarnott.plus.com/css_tutorial/test.htm]this[/url].

Now for the CSS bit. This stylesheet will change the text so that it is red and the headers so that they are blue:[pre] h1, h2 {color: blue;}p {color: red;}[/pre]
This will give you something like [url=http://www.stephenarnott.plus.com/css_tutorial/test2.htm]this[/url].

Now for something interesting. How about we make the h1 header hover in the top-right corner, no matter how far we scroll down the page? Well, all you need to do to the stylesheet is this:[pre] h1 {width: 100%; /* This bit is to make it be in the top-right corner */text-align: right;position: fixed; /* this is to make it float there */}h1, h2 {color: blue;}p {color: red;}[/pre]
And this will give you something like [url=http://www.stephenarnott.plus.com/css_tutorial/test3.htm]this[/url]. (Resize the browser window so it's very thin and short and it should work)

More later.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]
[img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img]

title: Re: Planet CK
content:
In the <head> section of your page, put this:[pre] <link href="style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />[/pre]This will load your CSS from a file named style.css - the trailing slash at the end is for XHTML compliance (which is good, but not essential). Then stick your CSS in the file you have linked to from your HTML page: in this case, you would put the CSS in a file named style.css.[url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url]

title: Re: Planet CK
content:
Pictures (or text, or almost anything) in front of pictures (or text, etc.) is possible by offsetting their coordinates.
Normally everything follows the "flow", which means top to bottom, left to right.
With CSS you can break away from that.

You can use a link to turn things invisible, but I think you need some kind of scripting language besides just HTML and CSS, for instance JavaScript.

I could Google up some links, but it's probably easier if you do it yourself and see which results you like.
Try some of these keywords:
css, flow, float, image, superimpose, visibility

Hmmm, I spent a few moments looking, and for some reason it's actually harder to find something with some good examples than I thought.
To tell you the truth I'm really not in the mood for searching right now, and I know there are some good sites out there.Retodon8

content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Oh, and i have some questions about java ******s.

1. Can they be games (mini games like tetris and space invaders)
2. Is Java easier to learn than C++?
3. Where can i get a good java compiler (looked but couldn't find one.)[hr][/quote]
1. Yes, but I think you'll need to track down and use an appropriate graphics library. Java's built in graphics may not handle the task. It depends on whether you need to draw a few simple shapes or a lot of bitmaps. Tetris or space invaders would be possible, although not beautiful, but Commander Keen would need a bit of help.

2. Yes, I suppose. Java offers fewer oppurtunities to fail spectacularly, but it's not exactly easy to write a game in any language. Java means a lot of typing though.

3. Sun's java SDK includes a compiler, and the NetBeans IDE. That's a good place to start.________________
